intro: Genipa vulcanicola, commonly known as the volcanic genipapo, is a rare and unique plant native to the volcanic soils of Central America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its small, fragrant flowers and edible, bright red berries. The plant thrives in nutrient-rich, well-drained soils and is adapted to the high temperatures and acidic conditions of volcanic regions. Its berries are used in local cuisines and traditional medicine, highlighting its ecological and cultural significance. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
